message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). STEC is commonly found in undercooked beef, making option D the correct choice. Mushrooms and shellfish can cause food poisoning, but not HUS. Raw pork can contain parasites that cause a different type of food poisoning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which is commonly caused by Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) found in undercooked beef. Avoiding consumption of undercooked beef would have most likely prevented his condition. None of the other options are known to cause HUS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and lab results suggest a diagnosis of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which is often caused by infection with Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC). Undercooked beef is a common source of STEC infection, so avoiding consumption of undercooked beef would have most likely prevented this patient's condition. Mushrooms, shellfish, and raw pork are not known to be associated with STEC infection or HUS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab values suggest Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which is a type of kidney failure. Among the options, only Undercooked beef is associated with E. coli O157:H7 infections, which can lead to HUS. The other options are not associated with this condition. Therefore, avoiding undercooked beef could have prevented this patient's condition.
